choices: clings to a parent or caregiver because he or she knows that the person can be trusted.
shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.
reaches out and explores because he or she knows that the parents are there as a safety net.
becomes acutely anxious in the presence of strangers or in unfamiliar surroundings.
front.question: In contrast to secure attachment, anxious-avoidant attachment occurs when a child:
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.

choices: An infant’s normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler’s normal body temperature.
An infant’s heart rate generally ranges between 70 and 110 beats/min.
An infant’s normal heart rate increases by 10 beats/min each month.
By six months of age, an infant’s normal tidal volume is 2 to 4 mL/kg.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding an infant’s vital signs is correct?
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: An infant’s normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler’s normal body temperature.

choices: 90 beats/min.
60 beats/min.
70 beats/min.
80 beats/min.
front.question: The average pulse rate of persons between 19 and 40 years of age is typically:
front.source: See Early Adults (19 to 40 Years)

cards.back: 70 beats/min.

choices: 10 to 18 months
18 to 24 months
6 to 8 months
24 to 36 months
front.question: At what age does separation anxiety typically peak in infants and small children?
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: 10 to 18 months

choices: Knows his or her name, can walk without any assistance
Walks without help, becomes frustrated with restrictions
Places objects in the mouth, pulls himself or herself up
Responds to his or her name, crawls around efficiently
front.question: Which of the following are noticeable characteristics of a 9-month-old infant?
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: Places objects in the mouth, pulls himself or herself up

choices: shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.
reaches out and explores because he or she knows that the parents are there as a safety net.
becomes acutely anxious in the presence of strangers or in unfamiliar surroundings.
clings to a parent or caregiver because he or she knows that the person can be trusted.
front.question: In contrast to secure attachment, anxious-avoidant attachment occurs when a child:
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: shows little emotional response to a parent or caregiver following repeated rejection.

choices: An infant’s tongue is proportionately larger than an adult’s tongue.
The rib cage of an infant is less flexible than an adult’s rib cage.
An infant’s head accounts for less body weight than an adult’s head.
The trachea of an infant is proportionately longer than an adult’s trachea.
front.question: Which of the following is an anatomic difference between children and adults?
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: An infant’s tongue is proportionately larger than an adult’s tongue.

choices: the back of the head is flat, which prevents a neutral position.
he or she has a long neck, which makes the trachea prone to collapse.
the occiput is proportionately large and the trachea is flexible.
the tongue is proportionately small and can fall back into the throat.
front.question: An infant or small child’s airway can be occluded if it is overextended or overflexed because:
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: the occiput is proportionately large and the trachea is flexible.

choices: 18 and 22 years.
21 and 30 years.
19 and 25 years.
25 and 35 years.
front.question: The human body should be functioning at its optimal level between the ages of:
front.source: See Early Adults (19 to 40 Years)

cards.back: 19 and 25 years.

choices: The normal respiratory rate in toddlers and preschoolers is between 12 and 20 breaths/min.
Toddlers and preschoolers have well-developed lung musculature, even though they have less lung tissue.
Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.
Muscle mass and bone density decrease in toddlers and preschoolers because of increased physical activity.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding toddlers and preschoolers is correct?
front.source: See Toddlers (1 to 3 Years) and Preschoolers (3 to 6 Years)

cards.back: Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.

choices: surface area of the alveoli increases.
diaphragm and intercostal muscles enlarge.
elasticity of the lungs decreases.
overall size of the airway decreases.
front.question: Breathing is often more difficult in older adults because the:
front.source: See Older Adults (61 Years and Older)

cards.back: elasticity of the lungs decreases.

choices: dilation of the blood vessels that supply the nephrons, which allows the kidneys to maintain their function.
a decreased ability to clear wastes from the body and a decreased ability to conserve fluids when needed.
the formation of large amounts of urine secondary to an increase in kidney mass of up to 20%.
a significant increase in filtration, which causes the excretion of large amounts of water from the body.
front.question: Age-related changes in the renal system result in:
front.source: See Older Adults (61 Years and Older)

cards.back: a decreased ability to clear wastes from the body and a decreased ability to conserve fluids when needed.

choices: a loss of respiratory muscle mass.
decreased residual volume.
increased surface area available for air exchange.
increased stiffness of the thoracic cage.
front.question: Factors that contribute to a decline in the vital capacity of an elderly patient include all of the following, except:
front.source: See Older Adults (61 Years and Older)

cards.back: increased surface area available for air exchange.

choices: blame their actions on what they have observed in older children.
act almost purely to avoid punishment and to get what they want.
make decisions based on their conscience.
look for approval from their peers and society.
front.question: In preconventional reasoning, children:
front.source: See School-Age Children (6 to 12 Years)

cards.back: act almost purely to avoid punishment and to get what they want.

choices: Adolescents are less fixated on their public image than younger children.
Family conflict decreases as the adolescent gains control of his or her own life.
Because they think rationally, adolescents are at the lowest risk for suicide.
Antisocial behavior and peer pressure peak around 14 to 16 years of age.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding psychosocial development in the adolescent age group is correct?
front.source: See Adolescents (12 to 18 Years)

cards.back: Antisocial behavior and peer pressure peak around 14 to 16 years of age.

choices: 90 to 140 beats/min.
100 to 150 beats/min.
70 to 120 beats/min.
60 to 100 beats/min.
front.question: The pulse rate of a child from ages 6 to 12 years is approximately:
front.source: See Introduction

cards.back: 70 to 120 beats/min.

choices: Because of a decrease in the number of brain cells, a person’s level of intelligence decreases with age.
The metabolic rate in the brain increases with age, but the consumption of oxygen decreases significantly.
Generally speaking, the brain increases in size by 10% to 20% by the time a person reaches 80 years of age.
Interconnections between brain cells often prevent a loss of knowledge or skill, despite a loss of neurons.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding age-related changes in the nervous system is correct?
front.source: See Older Adults (61 Years and Older)

cards.back: Interconnections between brain cells often prevent a loss of knowledge or skill, despite a loss of neurons.

choices: Increased weight
Overall health
Medical conditions
Medications
front.question: Which of the following is not a common factor that would affect a 75-year-old patient’s vital signs?
front.source: See Older Adults (61 Years and Older)

cards.back: Increased weight

choices: responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.
will readily allow you to separate her from her mother.
has bulging fontanelles secondary to severe dehydration.
is unable to track your movements with her eyes.
front.question: You are assessing a 13-month-old female who is running a fever and has been vomiting. While you are performing your physical examination on this child, you will most likely find that she:
front.source: See Neonates (Birth to 1 Month) and Infants (1 Month to 1 Year)

cards.back: responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.

choices: Increased cholesterol levels in the middle adult age group often do not respond to exercise and diet.
Significant impairments in hearing and vision begin to occur in persons between the ages of 41 and 44 years.
Cardiovascular health becomes an issue in this age group, as does the greater incidence of cancer.
Women in the middle adult age group typically experience menopause in their late 50s or early 60s.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding middle adults is correct?
front.source: See Middle Adults (41 to 60 Years)

cards.back: Cardiovascular health becomes an issue in this age group, as does the greater incidence of cancer.
